reviewText:
This game is a joke. I'll just list everything that is bad about it.
-Quite a bit of the artwork and animations are poor.
-The level design is basic.
-The enemies are either incredibly easy/bugged or are only hard because they are annoying.
-The gold drop rate seems low so if you want to buy stuff you have to spend a bunch of time mindlessly farming the spawner minions in the first level.
-There is no strategy, it is just hold down left click and occasionally move based on certain enemy attacks. Maybe this changes later on in the game but I just couldn't sit through the tedious starting levels to find out.
-The music is actually enjoyable but the clips are pretty short and they just play at random intervals with nothing in between

There are many other better, and cheaper, rogue-lites out there.
Would not recommend.

reviewText: It would be easy to write off Floors of Discomfort (FoD) within the first few minutes of game play, as I almost did (my first thought: This feels like it belongs on Kongregate."). That would be unfair though
date: because there really is more to it than first meets the eye.\n\nThe Overview: FoD is a platformer only inasmuch as you walk left or right killing things
hoursPlayed: really. The challenge comes with the sheer numbers of enemies thrown at you from the very start. For example
voteText: you can enter a new game and literally be overwhelmed with mobs in a matter of seconds (including one beastie who opens a portal through which other beasties can come). The more you play
votesHelpful: the more you realize that some strategy is necessary to ensure your survival.  Running away from (or jumping over) mobs is a viable option. Some mobs (and crates strewn about the levels) drop coins
votesTotal: which can be used in an in-game store to purchase power-ups. Treasure chests also might provide help (pray for the Speed Boost). The longer you survive
votesFunny: the more powerful you can become
commentsCount: but proper management of your extremely limited money is essential.  The "Rogue-lite" aspects of the game refer to the random item and mob placement
column16: the platform surface (although it might as well be designed
column17: as it doesn't feel any different from one game to the next) and sorta-kinda permadeath.\n\nThe Finer Points: The first thing I usually do in an Indie game is to turn off the music
column18: but it's actually above par here; I enjoyed the combination of atmospheric/dub/pop present in FoD (it also played continuously for me
column19: but there is at least one report of it playing intermittently). The power-ups are also creative and fun. The character models are interesting to look at
column20: and the hand-drawn art can be charming; at its  best
column21: it's reminiscent of The Binding of Isaac. I love the look of the shop
column23: although in higher resolutions (which cap out at 1600x900) items float above the shelves they should be resting on.  Unfortunately
column24: the rest of the play field (such as the background and platform surface) is dull and uninspired
column25: and the tiled patterns used don't gel with the hand-drawn art
column26: bringing down the overall look of the game.  The character animations are fairly fluid
column27: though.\n\nA couple of other things to consider: The controls cannot be remapped
column28: and gamepads don't seem to be implemented which
column30: seems a bit of an oversight. Finally
column31: there is only one character unlocked at the start of the game
column32: which means no choice for the player (a rarity in "Rogue-like" games).\n\nThings I'd like to see in a patch: Steam overlay integration. Trading cards and (especially) achievements; in a game this difficult
column34: achievements would go a long way to making it feel worth playing. I'd also like to see a crouch option
column35: but I suspect the entire enemy is hitboxed
column36: and not just the weapon it uses. Another character option at the start of the game would be great
column37: too; make the rest unlockable.  Different heights and gaps in the platform would definitely increase replay value
column38: although I'm sure that would involved re-coding enemy AI as well as the play field
column39: so I wouldn't really expect it.\n\nAll that said
column41: the game is pretty much complete
column42: and I enjoyed it once I realized it was deeper than it first appeared. It's something to pick up and play for short bursts when you want to beat the crap out of things and push yourself to do better "just one more time." It's priced about a buck too high
column43: but FoD is simple and fun
column46: less than the cost of a matinee ticket. Recommended."

reviewText: Floors of discomfort is a great game, and very entertaining with different routes to go down. It is very difficult, and I always think making a hard game is a lot, lot harder than just making an easy one. :D Good luck on your next game(s), I hope you're happier with them!\n

reviewText: I beat the game and found it enjoyable. I liked the art, gameplay, and unlockable characters. The art gives this game a distinct kind of character that you wont find in many other places. The music is also a plus. The characters in this game are diverse, and I enjoyed playing them, especially the Skelewizard. The gameplay is very basic, and easy to grasp. Progressing through the various floors" requires you to acquire items to make up for your character's shortcomings and counter the enemies ahead. I would buy this game if you have some spare change and want something to pass a bit of time with.\n\nThe game has a few flaws
date: mostly being glitches and a lack of a items. There is a decent amount of items in the game
recommended: some you can buy in the store
hoursPlayed: and some that you must pick up in chests and from bosses. I found that
helpfulPercent: in a short time I had already seen what I believe to be all of the items. It would be nice to see more items added to the game. I am happy with the items in the game so far
votesHelpful: as they all feel unique and helpful to some degree (except for temporary boost gems). While there may be some glitches
votesTotal: they were a minor inconvenienve to me.\n\nAll in all
votesFunny: I would purchase this short game if you are looking for a quick fix. While not a completely stellar game
column16: and you can't argue with the price."

reviewText: The keys do not correlate with the control instructions. Particularly 'F' which is supposed to open shop. Never does. The game itself is mediocre, but it could still be a little entertaining if you could actually play, as its ment to be played. Which you can't, because the keys to fit the commands. Oh yeah, and niether does any other key on the keyboard... or even numbers.
